entry.title: Diffusion model in SO(3) space
entry.content:
This theme supports rendering beautiful math in inline and display modes using MathJax 3 engine.

Why bother diffusion in SO(3) space?

One typical way to represent the structure of proteins is to use the position of alpha carbon and the rotation matrix of each residue. So the diffusion process on the space of alpha carbon is simple Euclidean space, but the diffusion process on the rotation matrix (\(SO(3)\) space) is non-Euclidean. This note aims to provide a rigorous formulation of diffusion model on \(SO(3)\) space.

Some definitions and identities

In this note, we do not always distinguish “group” and “representation of group”, just like physicists.

With notation from the article, we define the basis of the lie algebra of \(SO(3)\) group and their matrix representation as follows: \( egin{equation} egin{array}{ll} \mathbf{e}_1=\left[ egin{array}{l} 1 \ 0 \ 0 \ \end{array} ight] & G_1=\mathbf{e}_1^{ imes}=\left[ egin{array}{ccc} 0 & 0 & 0 \ 0 & 0 & -1 \ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{array} ight] \ \ \mathbf{e}_2=\left[ egin{array}{l} 0 \ 1 \ 0 \end{array} ight] & G_2=\mathbf{e}_2^{ imes}=\left[ egin{array}{ccc} 0 & 0 & 1 \ 0 & 0 & 0 \ -1 & 0 & 0 \end{array} ight] \ \ \mathbf{e}_3=\left[ egin{array}{l} 0 \ 0 \ 1 \end{array} ight] & G_3=\mathbf{e}_3^{ imes}=\left[ egin{array}{ccc} 0 & -1 & 0 \ 1 & 0 & 0 \ 0 & 0 & 0 \end{array} ight] \end{array} \end{equation}\)

Thus we can exponentiate the lie algebra matrix representation to get the matrix representation of $SO(3)$ group, and get back by taking the logarithm of \(SO(3)\) matrix.

The “box plus” operation is defined between a \(SO(3)\) matrix \(\Phi\) and a lie algebra vector \(\varphi\) egin{equation} \label{eq:0} oxplus: SO(3) imes \mathbb{R}^3 ightarrow SO(3), \quad (\Phi, oldsymbol{\varphi}) \mapsto \exp ( oldsymbol{\varphi}^{ imes}) \circ \Phi \end{equation}

The “box minus” operation is defined between two \(SO(3)\) matrix. egin{equation} oxminus: SO(3) imes SO(3) ightarrow \mathbb{R}^3, \quad (\Phi_1, \Phi_2) \mapsto \log \left(\Phi_1 \circ \Phi_2^{-1} ight) \end{equation}

\( extbf{Some important identities}\) (\( oldsymbol{v}\) is a vector in lie algebra, \( oldsymbol{v}^{ imes}\) is its matrix representation): egin{equation} \label{eq:1} \left( oldsymbol{v}^{ imes} ight)^T=- oldsymbol{v}^{ imes}, \left( oldsymbol{v}^{ imes} ight)^2= oldsymbol{v} oldsymbol{v}^T- oldsymbol{v}^T oldsymbol{v} oldsymbol{I}, (\Phi oldsymbol{v})^{ imes}=\Phi oldsymbol{v}^{ imes} \Phi^T \end{equation} Especially the third identities, which will play important roles in the derivation of the score function.

With these definitions, we can define the derivative of a scalar function with argument to be \(SO(3)\) matrix, egin{equation} \label{eq:2} rac{\partial f_3}{\partial \Phi}=\lim _{\epsilon ightarrow 0}\left[ egin{array}{l} rac{f_3\left(\Phi oxplus\left(\mathbf{e}_1 \epsilon ight) ight)-f_3(\Phi)}{\epsilon}
rac{f_3\left(\Phi oxplus\left(\mathbf{e}_2 \epsilon ight) ight)-f_3(\Phi)}{\epsilon}
rac{f_3\left(\Phi oxplus\left(\mathbf{e}_3 \epsilon ight) ight)-f_3(\Phi)}{\epsilon} \end{array} ight] \end{equation}

We can represent the \(SO(3)\) matrix in 3D space using axis-angle representation, in explicit terms, it can be written as: \(\overleftrightarrow{R}_n( heta)_{i, j}=n_i n_j+\cos heta \cdot\left(\delta_{i, j}-n_i n_j ight)-\sin heta \cdot \sum_c \epsilon_{i j k} n_k, ext { here } i, j, k=x, y, z\)

Or more simply written using lie algebra matrix: egin{equation} \overleftrightarrow{R}_n( heta)=\exp ( heta \overleftrightarrow{G} ullet n) \end{equation} where \( heta\) is in the range \([0, \pi]\), and \(n\) represents the rotation axis.

Prior distribution and random walk in SO(3) space

To understand the \(SO(3)\) group structure better, we can look at the double cover group of \(SO(3)\), the \(SU(2)\) group.

The Quaternion representation of \(SU(2)\) group can be represented by four Pauli matrices as: egin{equation} U=a_0 \sigma_0-\dot{\mathbb{I}}\left(a_1 \sigma_1+a_2 \sigma_2+a_3 \sigma_3 ight)=a_0 \sigma_0-\dot{\mathbb{I}} oldsymbol{a} \cdot oldsymbol{\sigma} \end{equation} where \(\sum_i a_i^2=a_0^2+ oldsymbol{a}^2=1\).

So the manifold of \(SU(2)\) group is a 3-sphere \(S^3\) in 4D Euclidean space.

Another way to write the quaternion representation is to use axis and angle by \(U = \exp \left(-\dot{\mathbb{I}} rac{ heta}{2} oldsymbol{n} ullet oldsymbol{\sigma} ight) = \left(\cos rac{ heta}{2}, \sin rac{ heta}{2} \cdot oldsymbol{n} ight)\). In this way of writing the \(SO(3)\) matrix can be represented as the adjoint representation of \(SU(2)\) group: \(e^{-\mathrm{i} rac{ heta}{2} oldsymbol{n} ullet \sigma} \cdot \sigma_a \cdot e^{\mathrm{i} rac{ heta}{2} n ullet \sigma}=\sum_b \sigma_b \cdot\left[\overleftrightarrow{R}_{ oldsymbol{n}}( heta) ight]_{ba}\) Notice that \(a_i\) and \(-a_i\) correspond to the same \(SO(3)\) matrix, so we have group structure isophism: \(\mathrm{SO}(3) \simeq \mathrm{SU}(2) / \mathbb{Z}_2\).

Since the manifold of \(SU(2)\) is \(S^3\), the Haar measure of \(SU(2)\) can be represented as: egin{equation} \mathrm{d} \mu(U)=\delta\Bigg(\sqrt{\sum olimits_{i=0}^3 a_i^2}-1\Bigg) \prod_{i=0}^3 \mathrm{~d} a_i \end{equation} On the other hand, we can parameterize the 4D coordinates as: \(\left(a_i ight)=r \cdot\left(\cos rac{ heta}{2}, \sin rac{ heta}{2}(\sin \vartheta \cos \phi, \sin \vartheta \sin \phi, \cos \vartheta) ight)\), so we can transform the measure in 4D coordinate space into the axis-angle space by computing the jacobian, namely egin{equation} \delta(r-1) \cdot\left| rac{\partial\left(a_0, a_1, a_2, a_3 ight)}{\partial(r, heta, \vartheta, \phi)} ight| \cdot \mathrm{d} r \mathrm{~d} heta \mathrm{d} \vartheta \mathrm{d} \phi= rac{1}{2} \sin ^2 rac{ heta}{2} \sin \vartheta \mathrm{d} heta \mathrm{d} \vartheta \mathrm{d} \phi = rac{1}{2} \sin ^2 rac{ heta}{2} \mathrm{~d} heta \cdot \mathrm{d}^2 oldsymbol{n} \end{equation} From this expression, we can know that in the axis-angle representation of the \(SU(2)\) group, the measure in angle space is proportional to \(\sin ^2 rac{ heta}{2} = 1 - \cos heta\), the measure in axis space is constant. Since the axis-angle representation of the \(SU(2)\) group has a two-to-one correspondence to the axis-angle representation of the \(SO(3)\) group with the same angle \( heta\) and axis \(n\), the measure in the axis-angle representation of the \(SO(3)\) group angle space is also proportional to \(1 - \cos heta\), and the measure in the axis space is uniform.

From another point of view, the prior distribution in the rotation angle space is proportional to \(1 - \cos heta\), and the prior distribution in the axis space is uniform.

Now we consider the noise adding process in \(SO(3)\) space. Like the random walk in 3D space, we apply small random rotation matrix on an initial matrix iteratively. We generate three small angles from a gaussain distribution, and compose them with Lie algebra matrix to get the rotation matrix. To write it formally, egin{equation} r^{(t+1)}=\exp \left\lbrace\sum_{d=1}^3 \epsilon_d G_d ight brace r^t \end{equation} Specifically, we set the standard deviation of the gaussian noise to be 0.2. After a certain number of steps, we can reach the final matrix of this process, we compute the rotation angle of this final matrix relative to the initial matrix, we can get the overall distribution of the rotation angle, as in the following figure, the left figure is the single step random walk, whose angle distribution corresponds to the so called IGSO3 distribution with the same standard deviation \(\sigma = 0.2\). egin{equation} f(\omega, \sigma)= rac{1-\cos \omega}{\pi} \sum_{l=0}^{\infty}(2 l+1) e^{-l(l+1) \sigma^2/2} rac{\sin \left(\left(l+ rac{1}{2} ight) \omega ight)}{\sin (\omega / 2)} \end{equation} The right figure is the ten steps random walk, whose angle distribution corresponds to the IGSO3 distribution with standard deviation \(\sigma = \sqrt{0.2^2 * 10} = 0.6325\).

Other choice of steps also give us consistency of the angle distribution with the IGSO(3) distribution, and its standard deviation is found to be the square root of the sum of the gaussian distribution, egin{equation} \sigma = \sqrt{ \sum_i \sigma_i^2} \end{equation} Note that in the limit of \(\sigma ightarrow \infty\), the function \(f(\omega, \sigma)\) will approach exactly \( rac{1-\cos \omega}{\pi}\), the prior distribution.

Forward process in SO(3) space

Since the marginal distribution of the random walk in \(SO(3)\) space is IGSO(3) distribution, we can simulate the forward process in \(SO(3)\) space by directly sampling angles from IGSO(3) distribution with a certain value of \(\sigma\), then sample an axis from an uniform distribution, then apply this random matrix upon the initial matrix. To write it formally: egin{equation} r^t=e^{ heta_t extbf{n}} r^0 \end{equation} where \( heta_t\) is sampled from the IGSO(3) distribution with standard deviation \(\sigma_t\), and \( extbf{n}\) is a 3D vector sampled from the uniform distribution.

With the addition theorem for the noise adding process, the matrices corresponding the neighboring distribution can be related by: egin{equation} r^t=e^{ eta_t extbf{n}} r^{t-1} \end{equation} where \( eta_t\) is sampled from the IGSO(3) distribution with standard deviation \(\sqrt{\sigma^2_t - \sigma^2_{t-1}}\), and \( extbf{n}\) is a 3D vector sampled from the uniform distribution.

Backward process in SO(3) space

A remarkable result from Anderson states that, the reverse SDE equation for a forward SDE process: egin{equation} \mathrm{d} \mathbf{x}=\mathbf{f}(\mathbf{x}, t) \mathrm{d} t+g(t) \mathrm{d} \mathbf{w} \end{equation} can be modeled as: egin{equation} \mathrm{d} \mathbf{x}=\left[\mathbf{f}(\mathbf{x}, t)-g(t)^2 abla_{\mathbf{x}} \log p_t(\mathbf{x}) ight] \mathrm{d} t+g(t) \mathrm{d} \overline{\mathbf{w}} \end{equation} Note that this formulation is in Euclidean space, in \(SO(3)\) case, we have to use the formulation in Lie algebra space, then exponentiate back to \(SO(3)\) space.

To write it more explicitly, we can write the random walk in Lie algebra space as: egin{equation} L_{t+1} = L_t + \mathbf{ eta_t} \cdot \mathbf{G} \end{equation} where \(\mathbf{ eta_t}\) is sampled from three gaussian distribution with standard deviation \(\sqrt{\sigma^2_t - \sigma^2_{t-1}}\), \(\mathbf{G}\) is the Three Lie algebra matrix.

Then the reverse process of this SDE in Lie algebra space is: egin{equation} L_t = L_{t+1} + (\sigma^2t - \sigma^2{t-1}) abla_{L^{(t)}} \log q\left(L_t ight) + \sqrt{\sigma^2t - \sigma^2{t-1}} \mathbf{\epsilon_t} \cdot \mathbf{G} \end{equation} Exponentiate back to the \(SO(3)\) matrix, we have the reverse process in \(SO(3)\) space: egin{equation} r^{(t-1)}=\exp \left{\left(\sigma_t^2-\sigma_{t-1}^2 ight) abla_{r^{(t)}} \log q\left(r^{(t)} ight)+\sqrt{\sigma_t^2-\sigma_{t-1}^2} \sum_{d=1}^3 \epsilon_d G_d ight} r^t, \end{equation} where \(q (r^{(t)}\) is the probability density of matrix \(r^{(t)}\) of the marginal distribution in the forward process. Now it is only a matter of calculating the expression \( abla_{r^{(t)}} \log q\left(r^{(t)} ight)\), which is also called the score function.

Score function in \(SO(3)\) space with trained model

At this stage, if we do not impose model information in the diffusion process, the marginal distribution of \(q(r^{(t)})\) is just the IGSO(3) distribution as a function of the rotation angle, then the score function is the derivative of the function w.r.t the three Lie algebra basis matrices, namely: egin{equation} abla_r \log q\left(r^{(t)} ight) =\left. abla_r \omega\left( ar{r}^{ op} r^{(t)} ight) rac{d}{d \omega} [ \log rac{ f\left(\omega ; \sigma_t^2 ight) } { 1 - \cos \omega} ] ight|_{\omega=\omega\left( ar{r}^{ op} r ight)} \end{equation} Note we divide the IGSO3 distribution by the measure in \(SO(3)\) space to get the probability density.

Now we impose model information in the diffusion process. First of all, according to the denoised score matching objective, we can use the conditional score to approximate the true score function: egin{equation} abla_r \log q\left(r^{(t)} ight) =\mathbb{E}q\left[ abla{r^{(t)}} \log q\left(r^{(t)} \mid r^{(0)} ight) \mid r^{(t)} ight] \end{equation} In real cases we do not know the distribution of the initial matrix $r^{(0)}$ given the current observation $r^{(t)}$. But if we have a trained model such that when observing a noised rotation matrix $r^{(t)}$, the model will output a single structure $\hat{r} (t)$ as the ground truth of the denoised structure. Then we can approximate the conditional score by the model prediction: egin{equation} egin{aligned} abla_r \log q\left(r^{(t)} ight) & \approx abla_{r^{(t)}} \log q\left(r^{(t)} \mid r^{(0)}=\hat{r}^{(0)} ight)
& = abla_{r^{(t)}} \log \mathcal{I} \mathcal{G}_{S O(3)}\left(r^{(t)} ; \hat{r}^{(0)}, \sigma_t^2 ight), \end{aligned} \end{equation}

Then the score function in \(SO(3)\) space can be written as: egin{equation} abla_r \log \mathcal{I} \mathcal{G}{S O(3)}\left(r ; \hat{r}, \sigma_t^2 ight)=\left. abla_r \omega\left(\hat{r}^{ op} r ight) rac{d}{d \omega} [ \log rac{ f\left(\omega ; \sigma_t^2 ight) } { 1 - \cos \omega} ] ight|{\omega=\omega\left(\hat{r}^{ op} r ight)} \end{equation} Note we divide the IGSO3 distribution by the measure in \(SO(3)\) space.

Now the crucial thing to compute is the derivative of the rotation angle with respect to the rotation matrix,namely egin{equation} abla_r \omega\left(\hat{r}^{ op} r ight) \end{equation} This is exactly the kind of derivatives defined in eq( ef{eq:2}), the derivative of a scalar function with respect to a \(SO(3)\) matrix.

Some important \( extbf{facts}\) before taking the derivatives is that, when doing matrix multiplication:

  1. \(SO(3)\) matrix do not generally commute (unless they have the same rotation axis).

  2. Infinitesimal rotation matrix commute to the first order of rotation angle.

  3. A \(SO(3)\) matrix and an infinitesimal rotation matrix do not generally commute (unless they have the same rotation axis).

Now let us take the derivative, I only show the first dimension of the derivative.

egin{equation} rac{\omega \left(\hat{r}^{ op}\left( r oxplus\mathbf{e}_1 \epsilon ight) ight)-\omega (\hat{r}^{ op} r)}{\epsilon} \end{equation}

Note that since \(SO(3)\) matrix acts on column vector, when we do matrix composition we will always extbf{apply the new matrix on the left of the old matrix}. This is why in eq ( ef{eq:0}) we apply the lie algebra exponential on the left of the original \(SO(3)\) matrix.

We proceed with the defintion of “box plus”, egin{equation} egin{aligned} rac{\omega \left(\hat{r}^{ op}\left( r oxplus\mathbf{e}_1 \epsilon ight) ight)-\omega (\hat{r}^{ op} r)}{\epsilon} & = rac{\omega \left(\hat{r}^{ op} (e^{\mathbf{e}_1 \epsilon } r ) ight) -\omega (\hat{r}^{ op} r)}{\epsilon}
& = rac{\omega \left(\hat{r}^{ op} (e^{\mathbf{e}_1 \epsilon } \hat{r} \hat{r}^{ op} r ) ight) -\omega (\hat{r}^{ op} r)}{\epsilon} \end{aligned} \end{equation}

Now using the third identity in eq( ef{eq:1}), we have egin{equation} egin{aligned} rac{\omega \left(\hat{r}^{ op}\left( r oxplus\mathbf{e}_1 \epsilon ight) ight)-\omega (\hat{r}^{ op} r)}{\epsilon} & = rac{\omega \left(\hat{r}^{ op} (e^{\mathbf{e}_1 \epsilon } r ) ight) -\omega (\hat{r}^{ op} r)}{\epsilon}
& = rac{\omega \left(\hat{r}^{ op} (e^{\mathbf{e}_1 \epsilon } \hat{r} \hat{r}^{ op} r ) ight) -\omega (\hat{r}^{ op} r)}{\epsilon}
& = rac{\omega \left( (e^{ \hat{r}^{ op} \mathbf{e}_1 \epsilon } \hat{r}^{ op} r ) ight) -\omega (\hat{r}^{ op} r)}{\epsilon} \end{aligned} \end{equation}

Now the crucial point is to compute the rotation angle from the composition of two rotation matrix.

extcolor{blue}{(Note that in general, we have the extbf{Baker–Campbell–Hausdorff formula}: egin{equation} Z= \log[e^X e^Y] = X+Y+ rac{1}{2}[X, Y]+ rac{1}{12}[X,[X, Y]]- rac{1}{12}[Y,[X, Y]]+\cdots \end{equation} But since we are dealing with \(SO(3)\) matrix, we have simpler formula, which is called “Rodrigues rotation formula.”})

The Rodrigues vector associated with a rotation matrix can be expressed as: egin{equation} \mathbf{g}=\hat{\mathbf{e}} an rac{ heta}{2} \end{equation} where \(\hat{\mathbf{e}}\) is the rotation axis unit vector, \( heta\) is the rotation angle.

When we combine two rotation matrix, we can get the Rodrigues rotation formula: egin{equation} (\mathbf{g}, \mathbf{f})= rac{\mathbf{g}+\mathbf{f}-\mathbf{f} imes \mathbf{g}}{1-\mathbf{g} \cdot \mathbf{f}} \end{equation} The rotation angle composition is expressed as follows: egin{equation} \cos rac{\gamma}{2}=\cos rac{ eta}{2} \cos rac{\alpha}{2}-\sin rac{ eta}{2} \sin rac{\alpha}{2} \mathbf{B} \cdot \mathbf{A}, \end{equation}

Now we assume that the Rodrigues vector associated with rotation matrix \(\hat{r}^{ op} r\) is \(\hat{A} an rac{\alpha}{2}\), the Rodrigues vector associated with rotation matrix \(e^{ \hat{r}^{ op} \mathbf{e}_1 \epsilon }\) is \(\hat{r}^{ op} \mathbf{e}_1 an rac{\epsilon}{2}\).

We express the rotation angle \(\omega \left( (e^{ \hat{r}^{ op} \mathbf{e}_1 \epsilon } \hat{r}^{ op} r ) ight)\) by \(\gamma\). We then have the equation: egin{equation} \cos rac{\gamma}{2}=\cos rac{\epsilon}{2} \cos rac{\alpha}{2}-\sin rac{\epsilon}{2} \sin rac{\alpha}{2} \hat{r}^{ op} \mathbf{e}_1 \cdot \mathbf{A}, \end{equation}

Since \(\epsilon\) is a small number, we taylor expand the equation: egin{equation} \cos rac{\gamma}{2}= \cos rac{\alpha}{2}- rac{\epsilon}{2} \sin rac{\alpha}{2} \hat{r}^{ op} \mathbf{e}_1 \cdot \mathbf{A}, \end{equation} We express \(\gamma\) to be the perturbation of \(\alpha\), \(\gamma = \alpha + \delta \alpha\), then taylor expand \(\cos rac{\alpha}{2}\), egin{equation} \cos rac{\alpha + \delta \alpha}{2} - \cos rac{\alpha}{2} = - \sin rac{\alpha}{2} rac{\delta \alpha}{2} = - rac{\epsilon}{2} \sin rac{\alpha}{2} \hat{r}^{ op} \mathbf{e}_1 \cdot \mathbf{A}, \end{equation} So we have the expression for \(\delta \alpha\), egin{equation} \delta \alpha = \epsilon \hat{r}^{ op} \mathbf{e}_1 \cdot \mathbf{A} \end{equation}

So we finally get the derivative, egin{equation} egin{aligned} rac{\omega \left(\hat{r}^{ op}\left( r oxplus\mathbf{e}1 \epsilon ight) ight)-\omega (\hat{r}^{ op} r)}{\epsilon} & = rac{\hat{r}^{ op}{xx} A_x + \hat{r}^{ op}{yx} A_y + \hat{r}^{ op}{zx} A_z}{\sqrt{A_x^2 + A_y^2 +A_z^2 }}
& = rac{\hat{r}{xx} A_x + \hat{r}{xy} A_y + \hat{r}_{xz} A_z}{\sqrt{A_x^2 + A_y^2 +A_z^2 }} \end{aligned} \end{equation}

Similarly we get the derivative in other two directions, egin{equation} rac{\omega \left(\hat{r}^{ op}\left( r oxplus\mathbf{e}2 \epsilon ight) ight)-\omega (\hat{r}^{ op} r)}{\epsilon} = rac{\hat{r}{yx} A_x + \hat{r}{yy} A_y + \hat{r}{yz} A_z}{\sqrt{A_x^2 + A_y^2 +A_z^2 }} \end{equation} egin{equation} rac{\omega \left(\hat{r}^{ op}\left( r oxplus\mathbf{e}3 \epsilon ight) ight)-\omega (\hat{r}^{ op} r)}{\epsilon} = rac{\hat{r}{zx} A_x + \hat{r}{zy} A_y + \hat{r}{zz} A_z}{\sqrt{A_x^2 + A_y^2 +A_z^2 }} \end{equation} Write in a compact form, using the identity egin{equation} \hat{r} v = \log (\hat{r} e^v \hat{r}^{ op}) \end{equation} egin{equation} abla_r \omega\left(\hat{r}^{ op} r ight) = rac{\hat{r} A}{\omega(\hat{r}^{ op} r)} = rac{\hat{r} \log(\hat{r}^{ op} r)}{\omega(\hat{r}^{ op} r)} = rac{ \log(r \hat{r}^{ op})}{\omega(\hat{r}^{ op} r)} = rac{r \log(\hat{r}^{ op} r)}{\omega(\hat{r}^{ op} r)} \end{equation} Note that the result is in the lie algebra space, which in \(\mathbb{R}^3\).

To use this score correctly, we need to first transform the vector into matrix representation. Then exponentiate it.

Note that MathJax 3 is a major re-write of MathJax that brought a significant improvement to the loading and rendering speed, which is now on par with KaTeX.

entry.content:
This post shows how to add bibliography to simple blog posts. We support every citation style that jekyll-scholar does. That means simple citation like (missing reference), multiple citations like (missing reference), long references like (missing reference) or also quotes:

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipisicing elit,
sed do eiusmod tempor.

If you would like something more academic, check the distill style post.

entry.title: a post with jupyter notebook
entry.content:
To include a jupyter notebook in a post, you can use the following code:

{::nomarkdown}
{% assign jupyter_path = 'assets/jupyter/blog.ipynb' | relative_url %}
{% capture notebook_exists %}{% file_exists assets/jupyter/blog.ipynb %}{% endcapture %}
{% if notebook_exists == 'true' %}
  {% jupyter_notebook jupyter_path %}
{% else %}
  <p>Sorry, the notebook you are looking for does not exist.</p>
{% endif %}
{:/nomarkdown}

Let’s break it down: this is possible thanks to Jekyll Jupyter Notebook plugin that allows you to embed jupyter notebooks in your posts. It basically calls jupyter nbconvert --to html to convert the notebook to an html page and then includes it in the post. Since Kramdown is the default Markdown renderer for Jekyll, we need to surround the call to the plugin with the ::nomarkdown tag so that it stops processing this part with Kramdown and outputs the content as-is.

The plugin takes as input the path to the notebook, but it assumes the file exists. If you want to check if the file exists before calling the plugin, you can use the file_exists filter. This avoids getting a 404 error from the plugin and ending up displaying the main page inside of it instead. If the file does not exist, you can output a message to the user. The code displayed above outputs the following:

Note that the jupyter notebook supports both light and dark themes.

entry.title: a post with custom blockquotes
entry.content:
This post shows how to add custom styles for blockquotes. Based on jekyll-gitbook implementation.

We decided to support the same custom blockquotes as in jekyll-gitbook, which are also found in a lot of other sites’ styles. The styles definitions can be found on the _base.scss file, more specifically:

/* Tips, warnings, and dangers */
.post .post-content blockquote {
  &.block-tip {
    border-color: var(--global-tip-block);
    background-color: var(--global-tip-block-bg);

    p {
      color: var(--global-tip-block-text);
    }

    h1,
    h2,
    h3,
    h4,
    h5,
    h6 {
      color: var(--global-tip-block-title);
    }
  }

  &.block-warning {
    border-color: var(--global-warning-block);
    background-color: var(--global-warning-block-bg);

    p {
      color: var(--global-warning-block-text);
    }

    h1,
    h2,
    h3,
    h4,
    h5,
    h6 {
      color: var(--global-warning-block-title);
    }
  }

  &.block-danger {
    border-color: var(--global-danger-block);
    background-color: var(--global-danger-block-bg);

    p {
      color: var(--global-danger-block-text);
    }

    h1,
    h2,
    h3,
    h4,
    h5,
    h6 {
      color: var(--global-danger-block-title);
    }
  }
}

A regular blockquote can be used as following:

> This is a regular blockquote
> and it can be used as usual

This is a regular blockquote and it can be used as usual

These custom styles can be used by adding the specific class to the blockquote, as follows:

> ##### TIP
>
> A tip can be used when you want to give advice
> related to a certain content.
{: .block-tip }
TIP

A tip can be used when you want to give advice related to a certain content.

> ##### WARNING
>
> This is a warning, and thus should
> be used when you want to warn the user
{: .block-warning }
WARNING

This is a warning, and thus should be used when you want to warn the user

> ##### DANGER
>
> This is a danger zone, and thus should
> be used carefully
{: .block-danger }
DANGER

This post shows how to add a table of contents as a sidebar.

Adding a Table of Contents

To add a table of contents to a post as a sidebar, simply add

toc:
  sidebar: left

to the front matter of the post. The table of contents will be automatically generated from the headings in the post. If you wish to display the sidebar to the right, simply change left to right.

entry.title: displaying beautiful tables with Bootstrap Tables

link.title: displaying beautiful tables with Bootstrap Tables

entry.content:
Using markdown to display tables is easy. Just use the following syntax:

| Left aligned | Center aligned | Right aligned |
| :----------- | :------------: | ------------: |
| Left 1       |    center 1    |       right 1 |
| Left 2       |    center 2    |       right 2 |
| Left 3       |    center 3    |       right 3 |

That will generate:

Left aligned Center aligned Right aligned
Left 1 center 1 right 1
Left 2 center 2 right 2
Left 3 center 3 right 3

It is also possible to use HTML to display tables. For example, the following HTML code will display a table with Bootstrap Table, loaded from a JSON file:

<table id="table" data-toggle="table" data-url="{{ '/assets/json/table_data.json' | relative_url }}">
  <thead>
    <tr>
      <th data-field="id">ID</th>
      <th data-field="name">Item Name</th>
      <th data-field="price">Item Price</th>
    </tr>
  </thead>
</table>
ID Item Name Item Price

By using Bootstrap Table it is possible to create pretty complex tables, with pagination, search, and more. For example, the following HTML code will display a table, loaded from a JSON file, with pagination, search, checkboxes, and header/content alignment. For more information, check the documentation.

<table
  data-click-to-select="true"
  data-height="460"
  data-pagination="true"
  data-search="true"
  data-toggle="table"
  data-url="{{ '/assets/json/table_data.json' | relative_url }}"
>
  <thead>
    <tr>
      <th data-checkbox="true"></th>
      <th data-field="id" data-halign="left" data-align="center" data-sortable="true">ID</th>
      <th data-field="name" data-halign="center" data-align="right" data-sortable="true">Item Name</th>
      <th data-field="price" data-halign="right" data-align="left" data-sortable="true">Item Price</th>
    </tr>
  </thead>
</table>
ID Item Name Item Price
